entry.title: Re: The Next Phase in the Deprecation of the Classic Experience in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hi,

We are being asked to migrate hundreds of Classic stories to Optimized yet not given the tools to do this... 

I have spent the last week talking to SAP regarding getting a simple list out if the system of ALL Classic stories and All those that have been Optimised (Unified not OVM) to date.  It would appear this simple ask is not currently possible!?!

Not only are OVM classed as Optimised in the System stats, which to my understanding is incorrect and these OVM are actulally Classic and need to be migrated also? please confirm that?

The system models only go back to April so we cant determine usage  to see what worth converting and models show some content as Null rather than classic or optimised or worse both null and one of these whatever that means. 

Most system models don't show Parent folder so are useless.

We also find bulk migration tool wont work with sub folders! Who doesn't use subfolders? Are we actually expected to go folder by folder?

The Q3 2025 release brought in Classic and Optmised story icons, these are displaying incorrectly and have raised this with SAP.

How is a large company actually expected to migrate huge quatities of content when we cant even get the basic value of classic and optimised stories out of the system in the first place?

The deprecation of classic content is poorly thought out,  tools are not in place to assist, migration is not like for like so requires rebuild, months of Analysts time wasted rebuilding what already exists for no value added.

Deprecation should be scrapped. Classic shoud remain as is and all new content Optimised, simple.

The we can concentrate on value added activites rather than wasting our time.

I look forward to finding out how we can get the info we need out of the system.

Regards

entry.title: Re: SAP CPI suppressing root and row elements in XML to J...
entry.content:
Hello,

You can use the below script to achive this:

 
def Message processData(Message message) {
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(message.getBody(java.lang.String.class))
    def rows = xml.row.collect { r ->
        [
            private_agency_code: r.private_agency_code.text(),
            branch_code        : r.branch_code.text()
        ]
    }    
    def out = JsonOutput.prettyPrint(JsonOutput.toJson(rows))
    message.setBody(out.toString())
    return message
}

entry.title: Re: EXTERNAL JOIN when using temporary tables
entry.content: Crystal Reports never removes the links; they are always present. Only the generated SQL code is different depending on the table types. If all linked tables are regular tables (or views), an INNER JOIN or OUTER JOIN is generated. As soon as at least one temporary table is involved, the links are mapped with EXTERNAL JOINS, even though the model is exactly the same and all tables are, of course, located in the same database. (My understanding of the documentation is that EXTERNAL JOINS are only used to merge data from different data sources.) I also tried removing the links and setting them again, but the result is the same. Crystal Reports obviously treats temporary tables differently to regular tables, and I would like to understand why.

entry.title: Re: Navigating the Future: Understanding Upcoming Changes to SAP Universal ID
entry.content:
Hi everyone, 

as there were some questions about how to deal in situation where a person is using the same email for several S-users. 

These users can set a password to their convenience. In case the user sets the same password to all users we recommend using the S/P-user Id and related password for login. Same applies to password reset in SAP IDS, the user needs then to use the related S/P-user to request a password reset.
 
SAP Support teams are already informed about this, if there are any questions relatedly to the UID password migration which started recently, they can simply reach out there to get help as well. 
An "account selector" will be available later this year which will allow you to select the appropriate users you are needing for the current login. This will be communicated accordingly once available. 
 
Please get in connection to SAP Support to get technical help, instead of posting things in this blog. 
 
Thanks and best regards.
Customer Identity Management Team

entry.title: Re: SAP CPI suppressing root and row elements in XML to J...
entry.content:
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.xml.*
import groovy.json.*

Message processData(Message message) {

  
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body)
    def list = xml.row.collect { row ->
        [
            private_agency_code: row.private_agency_code.text(),
            branch_code       : row.branch_code.text()
        ]
    }
    def json = JsonOutput.prettyPrint(JsonOutput.toJson(list))
    message.setBody(json)
    return message
}

 

just realized another answer also there

entry.title: Re: How to find the line items that made up settlement? T...
entry.content: Thanks for the information. I was able to determine that SAP applies the rounding difference to the last row in the distribution rule. For example if the total of all records settled is 17464.38 and the distribution percentage is 20% and there are five wbs elements the first four rows get 3,492.88 and the last row gets 3492.86. (17464.38 - (3492.88 * 4)) gives you the last row amount. But when dealing with individual rows (the rows that made up the total settled) you can only apply the distribution percentage and store as 3 decimal places, in the end the sum of all the line items add up to the amount settled across all wbs elements. SAP should have stored everything in 3 decimal places in my opinion.

entry.title: Sales Document BAdI Overview in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Sales Document BAdI Overview

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, customers' business processes can be fundamentally covered by SAP best practice solutions. To meet various customer business requirements, extensibility is essential. In terms of extensibility, Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are critical as they allow customers to implement custom logic to influence SAP standard business processes.

In SAP ECC or SAP PCE/OP, there are User-exits and VOFM Routines available that customer could update standard business object in business processings. As these techniques are not supported in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) become the most prevalent approach to influence SAP standard business processes. 

Up to SAP S/4HANA CE2508, there are following Cloud BAdIs defined in sales order processing. These Cloud BAdIs are called in well defined process sequence. For instance, the BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD is always processed before the BAdI "SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE". 

 

This blog explains the definition of Cloud BAdIs in sales order processing. I hope this blog can help you better understand sales order BAdIs and enable you to utilize them effectively in your business. 

Benefit of Sales Document BAdIs

The following benefits illustrate how sales document BAdIs can fulfill customer requirements:

  • Sales document Cloud BAdIs provide capabilities that enable customers to implement custom logic to influence the sales order process, regardless of the channel through which the sales order is processed.
  • Sales document Cloud BAdIs ensure that the custom logic is processed within the same LUW (Logic Unit of Work).
  • Since Cloud BAdIs are always triggered automatically, they reduce the complexity for business users and increase efficiency.

Definition of Sales Document BAdIs

Most sales document BAdIs are defined on following business contexts:

  • Sales: Sales Document (Header)
  • Sales: Sales Document Item (Item)

There are other business contexts used in sales BAdIs which work for some special sales business processes, such as:

  • Sales: Listing/Exclusion
  • Sales: Sales Order Request
  • Sales: Sales Scheduling Agreement Delivery Schedule
  • Sales: Text Determination

Since all sales document BAdIs are documented in SAP help, I will not explain them again in this blog. However, I will categorize those BAdIs into the following groups.

Pre-processing BAdIs

There is no official term for "Pre-processing BAdI" in SAP. Here, I would like to refer to all BAdIs that are triggered before the core processing of the sales document as "Pre-processing BAdIs," including the following:

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_BILCopying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Billing Documents)Sales: Sales DocumentYou can use this BAdI to provide routines for copying requirement from billing document to sales document
SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLSCopying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Sales Documents)Sales: Sales DocumentYou can use this BAdI to provide routines for copying requirement from sales document to sales document
SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEADData Transfer for Sales Document HeadersSales: Sales DocumentYou can implement this BAdI to influence the data transfer of copy control
EDI_SD_ORDER_MODIFY_HEADERHeader Modification for Sales Orders/Returns Orders in Inbound EDISales: Sales DocumentYou can implement this BAdI to update certain field of the EDI payload message
EDI_SD_ORDER_MODIFY_HEAD_PARTYHeader Partner Modification for Sales Orders/Returns Orders in Inbound EDISales: Sales DocumentYou can implement this BAdI to update certain field of the EDI payload message 
EDI_SD_INB_ORDER_TEXT_HEADMapping of Text Types for Header Texts in EDI Inbound ProcessingSales: Sales DocumentYou can implement this BAdI to map the text types n EDI inbound processing
SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_ITEM_BILCopying Requirements for Sales Document Items (from Billing Documents)Sales: Sales Document ItemYou can use this BAdI to provide routines for copying requirement from billing document item to sales document item
SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_ITEM_SLSCopying Requirements for Sales Document Items (from Sales Documents)Sales: Sales Document ItemYou can use this BAdI to provide routines for copying requirement from sales document item to sales document item
SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_ITEMData Transfer for Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to influence the data transfer of copy control
EDI_SD_ORDER_MODIFY_ITEMItem Modification for Sales Orders/Returns Orders in Inbound EDISales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to update certain field of the EDI payload message
EDI_SD_ORDER_MODIFY_ITEM_PARTYItem Partner Modification for Sales Orders/Returns Orders in Inbound EDISales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to update certain field of the EDI payload message
EDI_SD_INB_ORDER_TEXT_ITEMMapping of Text Types for Item Texts in EDI Inbound ProcessingSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to map the text types n EDI inbound processing

Transactional BAdIs

The transactional BAdI is processed in transactional manner during business object processing. It can be processed multiple times based on business object operation. For example, the sales order modify BAdI (SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD) is triggered as soon as sales order header is processed. 

Most sales document transactional BAdIs can influence sales document processes, for example, you can implement transactional BAdIs to modify sales document custom fields or certain standard fields. 

Since the sales document data is changed frequently by user interaction, the import parameters of the transactional BAdIs may not be stable. The field values set by custom logic could also be overwritten by standard logic or other custom logic due to dependencies. 

Below table lists transactional BAdIs in sales document process. 

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_SLS_CHECK_HEADCheck of Header Data in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales DocumentYou can implement custom logic to check sales document header data and raise messages
SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEMCheck of Item Data in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement custom logic to check sales document item and raise messages
SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEADModification of Header Custom Fields in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales DocumentIt is possible to modify custom fields on sales document header level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEMModification of Item Custom Fields in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales Document ItemIt is possible to modify custom fields on sales document item level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_BUSINESSModification of Business Data in Sales Document HeadersSales: Sales DocumentIt is possible to modify some standard fields on sales document header level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_BUSINESSModification of Business Data in Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemIt is possible to modify some standard fields on sales document item level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_TAXModification of Tax Data in Sales Document HeadersSales: Sales DocumentIt is possible to modify tax-relevant fields on sales document header level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_TAXModification of Tax Data in Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemIt is possible to modify tax-relevant fields on sales document item level via this BAdI
SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_REQDATE
Modification of Requested Delivery Date for Sales Document ItemsSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to modify requested delivery date on item level
SD_SLS_CHECK_DELETE_ITEMCheck of Sales Document Items Before DeletionSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement this BAdI to disallow deletion of sales document items

Final Phase BAdIs

The final-phase BAdI differs from the transactional BAdI because the final-phase BAdI is processed during the document save. Normally, the final-phase BAdI is called only once during the save process, and the import parameters are relatively more stable.

The user may not see the impact of the final-phase BAdI immediately during their interactions. In many cases, the user only sees the result after the business object is saved. The end user has limited control over the custom logic implemented in the final-phase BAdI.

In customer's end-to-end business, the final-phase BAdIs are quite important to fulfill various business requirements, especially for automated processes like API channel, integration channel, etc. 

Here are most used final-phase BAdIs in sales document process.

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_SLS_FINALIZEModification of Sales Document in Finalize Phase before Save

Sales: Sales Document 

Sales: Sales Document Item

It is possible to modify custom fields and some standard fields in sales document finalize phase before save
SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVECheck of Sales Documents Before Saving

Sales: Sales Document 

Sales: Sales Document Item

You can implement custom logic to validate sales document and prevent from saving document
SD_APM_SET_APPROVAL_REASONApproval Request Reasons for Sales DocumentsSales: Sales Document You can implement custom logic to control whether a sales document should trigger the workflow approval

Post-processing BAdIs 

Post-processing BAdIs are triggered after the sales document is processed, and normally do not prevent the sales document from being saved. 

Following BAdIs are categorized as post-processing BAdIs in sales document process.

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
EDI_SD_ORDER_CONF_OUT_HEADERHeader Modification for Sales Orders/Returns Orders in Outbound EDISales: Sales Document You can implement this BAdI to change the sales order EDI outbound message
EDI_SD_ORDER_CONF_OUT_ITEMItem Modification for Sales Orders/Returns Orders in Outbound EDISales: Sales Document You can implement this BAdI to change the sales order EDI outbound message
APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTSBAdI: Addition of Email RecipientsOutput Request Item You can implement this BAdI to add email recipients in sales document output items

Determination BAdIs 

There are some determination BAdIs triggered in sales document processing but not defined in sales document business context, e.g. listing/exclusion determination, text determination, pricing, etc. 

Following Cloud BAdIs are relevant to sales document processing.

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_LSTG_EXCLSN_RQMT_DOCRequirements in Listing/Exclusion for Sales DocumentsSales: Listing/Exclusion You can implement this BAdI to define requirement for listing/exclusion in sales documents
SD_LSTG_EXCLSN_RQMT_DOC_ITEMRequirements in Listing/Exclusion for Sales Document ItemsSales: Listing/Exclusion :  You can implement this BAdI to define requirement for listing/exclusion in sales document items
SD_TEXTS_COPY_REQUIREMENTCopying Requirement in Text DeterminationSales: Text Determination You can implement this BAdI to define requirement for text determination in SD documents
SD_TEXTS_DATA_TRANSFERData Transfer in Text DeterminationSales: Text Determination You can implement this BAdI to change the source text that transferred in sales documents
PRICING_DOCUMENT_REQUIREMENTDefine Requirement in Pricing for DocumentPricing You can implement this BAdI to control pricing requirement in sales documents
PRCG_DOCUMENT_ITEM_REQUIREMENT
Define Requirement in Pricing for Document ItemPricing You can implement this BAdI to control pricing requirement in sales document items

Things Behind the Scenes 

We often receive questions about sales document BAdIs from customers and partners in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Some of those questions are generic and applicable to many customers and partners, so it makes sense to share the details of those points here. 

Why are User-Exits not available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?

Answer: according to clean core extensibility guidance (see SAP note 3578329), user-exits are kind of modification and not supported in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Only the Cloud BAdIs and the released APIs are recommended in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

Why are only some fields from the sales document available as import parameters in the BAdI?

Answer: there are following reasons to decide what fields shall be exposed in Cloud BAdI as import parameter:

  • Field mapping is costly in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. We only expose most useful fields into Cloud BAdIs as parameters for performance consideration.
  • Only the Global Field Name (GFN) is allowed to be exposed in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Not all sales document fields have GFN defined. 

Why are many sales document standard fields not modifiable via Cloud BAdI?

Answer: it is always challenging to update sales document standard fields via custom logic because of dependencies. There are many standard logic processes that determine standard fields based on other fields during sales document processing. Inappropriate custom logic to update standard fields could lead to the following issues:

  • The standard field set by custom logic could be overwritten by standard logic 
  • Using Cloud BAdI to update standard fields might jeopardize standard sales document processes
  • Business object data could become inconsistent due to inappropriate custom logic determination

Therefore, only some sales document standard fields are possible to be modified by Cloud BAdIs. The product team is working hard to bring more changeable standard fields into Cloud BAdIs. 

Summary

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides many Cloud BAdIs that allow customers and partners to influence standard sales document processes for various business purposes. A better understanding of Cloud BAdIs can help customers and partners decide how to best utilize them to fulfill business requirements.

I will also introduce some blog posts that explain real use cases for specific sales document Cloud BAdIs. Please stay tuned for updates.

entry.title: Re: Error-No agents determined after execution of respons...
entry.content:
Hello,

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) helps you solve the issue?

When setting up a flexible workflow for supplier invoices based on a custom field, it is crucial to ensure that all configurations are correctly aligned. Here are some steps to troubleshoot the error you are facing:

  1. Verify Custom Field Mapping: Ensure that the custom field is correctly mapped in all relevant ‘Responsibility Management’ configuration settings. Double-check that the field is correctly assigned in the ‘Manage Teams and Responsibilities’ app.

  2. Check Workflow Activation: Make sure that the flexible workflow is activated 3170025 - Error ‘An error occurred while activating the workflow’ happens when activating supplier invoice flexible workflow in the ‘Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoices’ app. You can do this by navigating to the app and checking the status of the workflow.

  3. Review Approver Assignment: Sourcing and Procurement - Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoices Confirm that approvers are correctly assigned in the ‘Manage Teams and Responsibilities’ app. Ensure that the custom field is used in the responsibility definitions and that the approvers are linked to these definitions.

  4. Error Analysis: If the error persists, use the ‘Workflow Administration’ app to analyze the workflow issues. This app can provide insights into any missing configurations or errors in the workflow setup.

Please follow all steps described here: Flexible Workflow for Supplier Invoices

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: SAP CPI suppressing root and row elements in XML to J...
entry.content:
use the standard XML to JSON converter then it will have like 

{ "row": [ { "private_agency_code": "0000110033", "branch_code": "2100" }, { "private_agency_code": "0000110035", "branch_code": "2300" } ] }

then remove 

 { "row": }

with the Groovy code 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.*
import groovy.json.*

Message processData(Message message) {

    def body = message.getBody(String)
    def json = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
    def list = json.row
    def output = JsonOutput.prettyPrint(JsonOutput.toJson(list))
    message.setBody(output)
    return message
}

entry.title: (Solved) Use Case: Bulk Clone SAP Domains and Data Elements from CSV
entry.content:
Use Case: Bulk Clone SAP Domains and Data Elements from CSV with Description Retention

This ABAP program automates the cloning of multiple SAP domains and data elements by reading old and new names from a CSV file. It not only creates new objects but also copies their short text descriptions seamlessly using the SAP text management function modules READ_TEXT and SAVE_TEXT. The program supports both domains and data elements, offers file selection with F4 help, and activates newly created objects automatically. This solution significantly speeds up mass cloning tasks in SAP development, ensuring consistency and saving manual effort.

🚀 How to Use the Bulk Clone Tool for Domains & Data Elements

✨ **Prepare Your CSV File** ✨
- No headers, just clean comma-separated values (.csv)
- Keep it simple: use **ONE file at a time** for either **Domains** or **Data Elements** (don’t mix!)
- Format example:
* OLD_DOMAIN_NAME_1,NEW_DOMAIN_NAME_1
* OLD_DATAELEMENT_1,NEW_DATAELEMENT_1

🚀 **Run the Program** 🚀
- Hit **F4** to open the file browser & pick your CSV
- Check the boxes for **Domains** and/or **Data Elements** to match your file
- Press **Execute** and watch the magic happen!
- Keep an eye on the screen logs for ✔️ success messages or ⚠️ warnings

abap program -

REPORT zclone_doma_dtel_from_csv1.

TYPE-POOLS: truxs.
************************************************************************
* SELECTION SCREEN
************************************************************************
PARAMETERS: p_path TYPE rlgrap-filename OBLIGATORY,
            p_doma AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT 'X',
            p_dtel AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT 'X'.

************************************************************************
* TYPES & VARIABLES
************************************************************************
TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_mapping,
         old_name TYPE ddobjname,
         new_name TYPE ddobjname,
       END OF ty_mapping.

DATA: lt_mapping TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_mapping,
      ls_mapping TYPE ty_mapping,
      lt_raw     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF string,
      lv_line    TYPE string,
      lt_files   TYPE filetable,
      lv_rc      TYPE i,
      lv_file    TYPE string,
      lv_fname   TYPE string,
      lv_name    TYPE thead-tdname.

DATA: ls_doma        TYPE dd01v,
      ls_doma_text   TYPE dd01t,
      ls_dtel        TYPE dd04v,
      ls_dtel_text   TYPE dd04t,
      lt_texts       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF itctc,
      ls_text        TYPE itctc.

************************************************************************
* F4 HELP FOR FILE PATH
************************************************************************
AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_path.
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>file_open_dialog
    EXPORTING
      window_title      = 'Select CSV File'
      default_extension = 'csv'
      file_filter       = 'CSV Files (*.csv)|*.csv|All Files (*.*)|*.*'
    CHANGING
      file_table        = lt_files
      rc                = lv_rc
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS            = 1.
  IF sy-subrc = 0 AND lv_rc > 0.
    READ TABLE lt_files INTO lv_file INDEX 1.
    p_path = lv_file.
  ENDIF.

************************************************************************
* START OF SELECTION
************************************************************************
START-OF-SELECTION.

  lv_fname = p_path.

  " Upload CSV
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload
    EXPORTING
      filename = lv_fname
      filetype = 'ASC'
    CHANGING
      data_tab = lt_raw
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS   = 1.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'Error uploading file' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Parse CSV
  LOOP AT lt_raw INTO lv_line.
    SPLIT lv_line AT ',' INTO ls_mapping-old_name ls_mapping-new_name.
    APPEND ls_mapping TO lt_mapping.
  ENDLOOP.

************************************************************************
* COPY DOMAINS
************************************************************************
  IF p_doma = abap_true.

    LOOP AT lt_mapping INTO ls_mapping.

      CLEAR: ls_doma, ls_doma_text, lt_texts, ls_text.

      " Get original domain definition
      CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_DOMA_GET'
        EXPORTING
          name = ls_mapping-old_name
        IMPORTING
          dd01v_wa = ls_doma
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS = 1.
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        WRITE: / '❌ Domain not found:', ls_mapping-old_name.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      " Change name
      ls_doma-domname = ls_mapping-new_name.

      " Put new domain
      CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_DOMA_PUT'
        EXPORTING
          name     = ls_mapping-new_name
          dd01v_wa = ls_doma
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS = 1.
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        WRITE: / '❌ Error creating domain:', ls_mapping-new_name.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      " Copy long texts
      CLEAR ls_text.
      ls_text-destobject = 'DD01T'.
      ls_text-destname   = ls_mapping-new_name.
      ls_text-destid     = 'DOMA'.
      ls_text-destlang   = sy-langu.
      ls_text-srcobject  = 'DD01T'.
      ls_text-srcname    = ls_mapping-old_name.
      ls_text-srcid      = 'DOMA'.
      ls_text-srclang    = sy-langu.
      APPEND ls_text TO lt_texts.

      CALL FUNCTION 'COPY_TEXTS'
        EXPORTING
          savemode_direct = 'X'
          insert          = 'X'
        TABLES
          texts           = lt_texts
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS          = 1.

      " Copy short description (DD01T)
      SELECT SINGLE * FROM dd01t INTO ls_doma_text
       WHERE domname = ls_mapping-old_name AND ddlanguage = sy-langu.
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        ls_doma_text-domname = ls_mapping-new_name.
        INSERT dd01t FROM ls_doma_text.
      ENDIF.

      " Activate domain
      CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_DOMA_ACTIVATE'
        EXPORTING
          name = ls_mapping-new_name
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS = 1.

      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        WRITE: / '✅ Domain created:', ls_mapping-new_name.
      ELSE.
        WRITE: / '⚠️ Domain activation failed:', ls_mapping-new_name.
      ENDIF.

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDIF.

************************************************************************
* COPY DATA ELEMENTS
************************************************************************
  IF p_dtel = abap_true.

    LOOP AT lt_mapping INTO ls_mapping.

      CLEAR: ls_dtel, ls_dtel_text, lt_texts, ls_text.

      " Get original data element
      CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_DTEL_GET'
        EXPORTING
          name = ls_mapping-old_name
        IMPORTING
          dd04v_wa = ls_dtel
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS = 1.
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        WRITE: / '❌ Data element not found:', ls_mapping-old_name.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      " Change name
      ls_dtel-rollname = ls_mapping-new_name.

      " Put new data element
      CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_DTEL_PUT'
        EXPORTING
          name     = ls_mapping-new_name
          dd04v_wa = ls_dtel
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS = 1.
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        WRITE: / '❌ Error creating data element:', ls_mapping-new_name.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      " Copy long text
      CLEAR ls_text.
      ls_text-destobject = 'DD04T'.
      ls_text-destname   = ls_mapping-new_name.
      ls_text-destid     = 'DTEL'.
      ls_text-destlang   = sy-langu.
      ls_text-srcobject  = 'DD04T'.
      ls_text-srcname    = ls_mapping-old_name.
      ls_text-srcid      = 'DTEL'.
      ls_text-srclang    = sy-langu.
      APPEND ls_text TO lt_texts.

      CALL FUNCTION 'COPY_TEXTS'
        EXPORTING
          savemode_direct = 'X'
          insert          = 'X'
        TABLES
          texts           = lt_texts
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS          = 1.

      " Copy short description (DD04T)
      SELECT SINGLE * FROM dd04t INTO ls_dtel_text
       WHERE rollname = ls_mapping-old_name AND ddlanguage = sy-langu.
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        ls_dtel_text-rollname = ls_mapping-new_name.
        INSERT dd04t FROM ls_dtel_text.
      ENDIF.

      " Activate
      CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_DTEL_ACTIVATE'
        EXPORTING
          name = ls_mapping-new_name
        EXCEPTIONS
          OTHERS = 1.

      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        WRITE: / '✅ Data element created:', ls_mapping-new_name.
      ELSE.
        WRITE: / '⚠️ Data element activation failed:', ls_mapping-new_name.
      ENDIF.

    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.

💡 Tips for Creating Large Numbers

✅ Test with 5–10 entries first to ensure structure and naming is correct.

⏳ For large uploads, consider running it as a background job (via SM36).

entry.title: Re: In the Purchase Order creation screen, under the Cond...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To display customs duty in INR on the Purchase Order screen, you can consider using custom logic or routines that handle currency conversion. Planned Delivery Cost of Purchasing in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition However, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the standard functionality may not directly support displaying a condition value in a different currency than the document currency during PO creation.

Steps to Consider:

  1. Custom Logic for Currency Conversion: You might need to implement custom logic to convert the customs duty Enhance custom logic by conversion of decimal places for currencies in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition from USD to INR during the PO creation process. This involves using Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) or custom CDS views to handle currency conversion.

  2. Custom CDS Views: Create a custom CDS view that includes currency conversion logic. This view can be used to display the converted values in INR.

  3. Custom Analytical Queries: Use custom analytical queries to display the converted values in INR. This can be set up to show the values in the desired currency.

  4. Routine Number for Conversion: While there is no specific routine number mentioned for currency conversion in the provided context, you can explore using custom routines in your pricing procedure to handle currency conversion.

Example:

  • Condition Type: JCDB (Basic Custom)
  • Desired Currency: INR
  • Document Currency: USD

By implementing custom logic, you can ensure that the customs duty is calculated and displayed in INR at the PO creation stage, allowing for review before finalizing the PO.

 

[1] Planned Delivery Cost of Purchasing in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
[2] Enhance custom logic by conversion of decimal places for currencies in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
Kind regards,
Henrike

entry.title: Re: Convert SAP BTP Certificate Service Keys to PFX Files
entry.content:
Thanks, @JG_LEE!

I know, using certificates requires more effort and might even come with additional costs (when official CAs are involved), but you should use them wherever possible, since they are more secure. Especially for production environments.

Unfortunately, I'm not a CAP specialist. I think CAP can use the Connectivity/Destination service of SAP BTP.
If your CAP app will be used by different users to access APIs of other systems, you should consider using OAuth instead of basic or certificate-based authentication. Basic and cert auth would access the REST APIs with a fixed user and fixed permissions, no matter what actual permissions the currently logged-in user has. OAuth allows the app to "impersonate" the logged-in user when calling the REST APIs. It calls them on behalf of the user and ensures that only resources can be accessed where the user really has permissions for.

I'm not sure if this is in anyway helpful for your question. Otherwise, I can recommend asking this in the following live session: SAP BTP Extensibility for SAP CX solutions - CAP

entry.title: Re: How does CSRF token work? SAP Gateway
entry.content: @shreyashagrwl sorry for the really late response. The REST principle of being stateless is often misunderstood like that. It is the server that has to be stateless, while the client can be stateful. To preserve the state on the client, the best practice is to use cookies. Cookies are generated by the server but are not stored by the server, but the client. If the client sends the cookies then the server can validate them.

entry.title: Re: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL An...
entry.content:
"a single LOAD TABLE statement might be not even atomic. I'd asked for that a while ago"
So you want an LOAD TABLE that just loads whatever data it can? You can use "ALLOW ALL ERRORS" and this would get you close to those semantics. It would work provided the statement completes. If the client disconnects or the server shuts down during the LOAD, it would still be rolled back.

You can even use the ROW LOG syntax to write the data out that could not be LOAD. That was fun to write -- especially for cases where character set translation is required. The row log is written in the same character set as the original input file.

entry.title: Business Application Studio Cannot See BTP Destinations (Platform Issue)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am facing a persistent issue where my Business Application Studio dev space is unable to see a BTP destination I've configured. The destination itself is set up correctly and the connection to my on-premise system is working perfectly, but it does not appear in the Fiori generator.

Environment:

  • BTP Environment: Trial Account

  • Region: US East (VA) - AWS

  • BAS Dev Space Type: SAP Fiori

Summary of the situation:

  1. I have successfully installed and configured the SAP Cloud Connector.

  2. I have created a destination in my BTP subaccount that connects to my on-premise SAP system. This destination has the required properties: HTML5.DynamicDestination = true and WebIDEUsage = odata_gen.

  3. Crucially, when I click the "Check Connection" button for this destination in the BTP Cockpit, the check is successful and returns a "200 OK - Backend is reachable" message. This confirms the entire end-to-end connection is working correctly.

  4. However, when I go into a Business Application Studio dev space and use the SAP Fiori generator, this destination does not appear in the "System" dropdown list.

  5. I have tried restarting the dev space, which did not solve the issue. I then deleted the dev space and created a brand new "SAP Fiori" dev space, and the destination is still not visible.

  6. When I run the diagnostic command npx fiori-tools destination in the terminal of the new dev space, I receive a DNS error:

    npm ERR! code ENOTFOUND
npm ERR! syscall getaddrinfo
npm ERR! errno ENOTFOUND
npm ERR! request to https://.../_.../destinations failed, reason: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND ...

This ENOTFOUND error in a brand new dev space, combined with the successful connection check in the cockpit, strongly suggests a platform-level DNS or networking issue within the BAS environment for my trial account.

Could you please advise if this is a known issue or what the next steps should be? I believe I have exhausted all possible configuration and troubleshooting steps.

Thank you for your help.

entry.title: Why an organisation should always strive to keep a clean core in all transformation projects
entry.content:
What is a transformation Journey and why would a business choose to begin one?

There are many issues faced by businesses today in the ever-continuing goal to become ‘best run’. Some of these issues include natural disasters, geopolitical tensions such as tariffs, wars and other events that previously were once in a lifetime events, these are now the new common challenges of businesses in the modern age. Any one of these challenges or multiple of them combined can prompt a business to embark on a transformation journey.

An Enterprise small or big who wishes to unlock the full potential of their business in any sort of business landscape must leverage information technology as an important tooling. In a partnership with SAP, this enterprise can employ a guided transformation journey such as RISE with SAP. A transformation journey can be intimidating but with guided transformation journeys like RISE, the process can be simplified. [1]

Some motivations for the transformation could include:

  1. The Increasing Disruption of Global Supply Chains:
    Global supply chains are increasingly vulnerable to disruptions that highlight the critical need for resilience, agility, and the ability to adapt quickly. Events such as the EverGiven ship blockage in the Suez Canal illustrate how a single incident can unravel an entire organization crippling production schedules, depleting inventory levels, and significantly impacting customer satisfaction.
  2. Challenges in Meeting Evolving Customer Expectations:
    Modern businesses face a paradigm shift in managing customer expectations. The era of simple B2C (business-to-consumer) engagements has evolved into consumers demanding personalized solutions tailored to their specific needs. Additionally, customers expect businesses to prioritize sustainability and adhere to ethical practices, requiring organizations to be agile and responsive to changing societal demands. it is not enough for a business to simply sell shoes or clothes anymore. They need to ensure ethical sourcing and reduced carbon footprint for there entire chain of business.
  3. The Pressure to Keep Pace with Technological Advancements:
    Rapid technological advancements are transforming industries across the globe. Businesses must embrace innovation to stay competitive. whether that involves adopting AI-driven insights, enabling real-time data analysis, or leveraging automation to streamline operations. Falling behind in technology adoption not only puts companies at a disadvantage but can also limit their ability to innovate and scale efficiently.
  1. Some additional motivations for customers who undergo a transformation journey such as rise with sap could include the need for real time insights into their business, increasing the robustness and responsiveness of their systems, increased cloud flexibility and ability to maneuver operations to take advantage of new opportunities or to avoid potential downfalls.

Due to these challenges and new business opportunities a business might decide to embark on a transformation journey; from an old ERP System to a newer one in efforts to take advantage of the benefits of the cloud such as increased agility and ability to scale. [2] New modern comprehensive packages like S4HANA Cloud can provide this.  In this transformation journey, an important choice must be made. The choice is whether to opt for a brand-new implementation (greenfield) or a system conversion (“brownfield”) implementation strategy. [3] The challenges in keeping the core clean in these two implementation strategies are different.  [4]

While these benefits can be realized from a transformation process, they can be undermined by the negative effects that may arise if the customer fails to prioritize maintaining a clean core. Keeping the core processes clean and free of irrelevant customizations reduces technical debt, improved business adaptability and enables more agile businesses are key principles that define the importance of clean core. [5]

 

What is the clean core strategy and why is it necessary?

From the dawn of Enterprise Resource Planning “Keeping the core clean” has always been a goal. Although most businesses might believe they are completely different in terms of business structure or complexity, enterprise resource planning [6]

Clean core simply represents the ERP system without any baggage such as layers and layers of custom code, it means keeping your ERP System close to SAP Defined standard as much as possible while handling the integrations of extensions and modifications through SAP Defined best practices.  [5]. Clean means Up to date, transparent, unmodified, consistent, efficient and cloud compliant, Core means the main aspects of an ERP system landscape, the extensibility, data, integration and processes. [7]

Following a clean core strategy includes the active efforts to reduce data and process inconsistencies, establish suitable housekeeping processes and governance structures, maximizing the use of SAP’s standard functionality and minimizing the complexity of customization [7]

 

SAP’S Clean Core Approach.

A business operating at its optimal core will have an up-to-date system with cloud-compliant extensions and seamless integration. SAP for a long time has offered extensive capabilities for its software to be extended primarily through ABAP. Businesses were able to tailor the software to their specific market needs. However this freedom to customize however lead to significant long-term challenges that were expensive both financially and in terms of time. Customers who frequently customize functionality to align with a specific process result in the creation of thousands of custom objects, often lacking proper governance and documentation.

This technical debt can result in security vulnerabilities, degraded performance, and widespread system instability, making upgrades and transformations costly, complex, and time-consuming, effectively trapping companies in outdated software. Clean core emerged as a response to these challenges, addressing past architectural limitations by shifting from “in-core” ABAP customization to low-code, no-code, pro-code, and side-by-side solutions available on SAP BTP. [9]

 

 

Clean Core and its benefits during and after a transformation project.

There are multiple approaches to applying a clean core transformation; In a greenfield scenario, we can start from fresh and adopt a clean core from the beginning. This approach enables us to get all the key benefits of clean core right out of the box. On the contrary, however, a brownfield approach allows the new instance to maintain some of the old instance’s complexities and possibly unwanted customizations. In this scenario we must embark on a journey to get the core to become clean.  

Businesses may adopt a brownfield approach when existing processes are too complex or costly to restart, opting instead to preserve core operations. Yet even in these cases, maintaining a clean core is critical. A CTO evaluating the effort will inevitably ask: what is in it for us with clean core?

Keeping a clean core at heart implies a minimization of the need for custom code. Which directly translates into lower maintenance cost. This approach will reduce the total cost of ownership due to reducing maintenance. Also, technical debt which is the accrued cost of past fixes and nonstandard implementations, will also be a significant drain on the budget of an IT department saddled with an unclean core after a brownfield project is complete. [8]  

By working towards a clean core, organizations might begin to see a reduction in the total cost of ownership of the software and the ability to deploy its resources towards newer business issues rather than trying to solve the problem that comes from an accrual of technical debt. Keeping to the clean core emphasis on standard functionality helps in the development of a more robust and predictable system which directly enhances user productivity and satisfaction.

Keeping a clean core can enable more swifter updates. Some firms have reported cutting upgrade timelines by as much as 40%., traditionally as any large business who has implemented an ERP Solution will tell you upgrades are slow, and extremely expensive. Clean core changes this dynamic by decoupling custom logic which enables businesses to consume SAP’s Innovation rapidly. [8]

Having a clean core could also leave a business better equipped to handle various regulation and security standards. A clean core environment is easier to monitor as there are now clearer boundaries between the core ERP System. Reduced complexity will also lead to a higher level of security as fewer entry points are now present within the system. [8]

To support the clean core journey SAP, a strong advocate of maintaining a clean core both during and after a transformation provide instruments to enable the achievement and sustenance of clean core. In a clean core architected environment as recommended, the architectural approach as provided by sap supports the extension of features through well-defined public APIs, Business events which is a system generated notification in the ERP that something has occurred eg: a purchase order has been approved, or a goods movement has been posted.  [4]

External applications can subscribe to the event and trigger processes or workflows. This new approach by SAP removes the need for modifying the core of the software allowing for loose coupling. It enables businesses to react to change in real time without the need to modify the ERP of the software.

This approach means it is now easier to swap out, update or add new functionality with minimal disruption enabling the workforce to take advantage at any key moment of the new benefits offered by the cloud environment after a transformation project to S4HANA.

Beyond technical best practices the SAP clean core strategy of enabling teams to extend the system alongside the core rather than modifying it directly provides more room to build, test, and iterate without compromising stability. For example, one SAP customer experienced a four-month delay during a scheduled rollout due to dependencies tied to their legacy Z-code. Such delays can be costly in time, money, and momentum. By reducing reliance on core modifications, clean core emphasizes modular development, where individual components contribute to overall system agility.

Achieving and Sustaining Clean Core after the transformation project

 

 

The main goals to maintain clean core after the transformation.

Since our organizational goal is to achieve and maintain a clean core, it is essential to define the key components and indicators of a clean core, as well as the practices required to preserve it.

  1. Clean Extensions
  2. Clean Business Processes
  3. Clean Data

Clean Extensions: After the transformation journey is completed, a business need or requirement might provide a situation in which the business needs to add extensions to their ERP Systems. Extensions could help to meet various needs while providing immense value; but in order not to ruin the efforts we have undertaken so far to keep the core clean; it is important that we ensure they are implemented in a clean core compliant manner.

S4HANA is feature-rich, so organizations should critically assess the need for extensions before creating them, as the required functionality may already be available through SAP BTP. Extensions must be designed to support seamless ERP upgrades, avoiding risks or disruptions. Development teams should fully understand the requirements before starting and determine whether an extension should be implemented on-stack or side-by-side. Classical extension techniques are strongly discouraged, as they increase the likelihood of system instability, upgrade failures, and higher maintenance costs.

If, after evaluating all features, a business still requires extensions to meet its objectives, they should be implemented either internally within S4HANA Cloud as on-stack extensions or externally as side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP. SAP’s ABAP Cloud Development Model (CDM) enforces the use of released APIs and applies syntax checks to ensure compliance.

Keeping extensions clean is essential because poorly designed or non-compliant extensions can cause upgrade delays, break business-critical processes, introduce security vulnerabilities, and significantly increase long-term maintenance overhead. By minimizing unnecessary extensions, ensuring compliance with cloud standards, and aligning with customer requirements, organizations can maximize ERP effectiveness while maintaining a clean core.

 

Diagram of clean core extensibility with BTP.

Clean Business Processes: Organizations aiming to maintain a clean core must establish a strong organizational structure with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. This structure, combined with the selection of scalable, secure technological tools, forms the foundation for maintaining clean processes. During and after the transformation, tools such as Signavio Process Manager and Signavio Process Governance enhance process visibility, improve internal compliance, and accelerate business process optimization. [11]

By leveraging these solutions within a clean core environment, businesses can better understand their processes, identify root causes of issues more easily, and reduce both transformation time and risk outcomes that are far harder to achieve without a clean process core. Well-documented, efficient processes also help organizations remain competitive in a fast-paced business environment, ultimately leading to stronger results.

Clean Data: In the cloud and digital age, clean, usable data is one of the most valuable assets for organizations, enabling faster decision-making and actionable insights. Following a transformation to S4HANA Cloud, businesses gain a robust platform for managing, processing, and applying data effectively.

However, data is only as valuable as the processes and principles that ensure its cleanliness. The three main pillars of clean data are:

  • Accuracy: Data must reflect the true state of the business. Without proper validation rules, regular quality checks, and governance, inaccurate data can lead to faulty decisions, inefficient processes, and reduced user trust. Regular audits and automated checks help prevent these issues.
  • Completeness: Incomplete data undermines decision-making and trust. Businesses should enforce standardized data entry, validation processes, and comprehensive collection practices to maintain completeness.
  • Consistency: Data must be uniform across systems. Inconsistencies create confusion, errors, and inefficiencies. Maintaining standards, conducting profiling, and implementing integration and reconciliation processes are critical to consistency. [4]

Maintaining a clean core with respect to data maximizes the value derived from data, enhances process efficiency, and reduces total cost of ownership by enabling efficient management of data volumes and reliable results from business processes.

Conclusion

Regardless of the motivations for a transformation journey, maintaining a clean core during and after the process delivers significant organizational value. Beyond reducing total cost of ownership, a clean core enables the adoption of the latest innovations a critical advantage in the AI-driven era and provides the flexibility to meet evolving business objectives.

The five pillars of clean core represent more than a technological change; they signify a mindset and paradigm shift from on-premise to cloud-based systems. This shift affects custom code, data, processes, and overall business operations, keeping them effective and efficient.

When combined with a transformation initiative, a clean core unlocks a new operational paradigm, maximizing business potential and supporting the development of a sustainable, best-run enterprise. Given these combined benefits, it is clear that maintaining a clean core during a transformation journey is in the best interest of any organization.

References

[1]

"lemongrasscloud," April 2024. [Online]. Available: https://lemongrasscloud.com/articles/advantages-rise-with-sap/.

[2]

K. Bowman, "pathlock," March 2025. [Online]. Available: https://pathlock.com/blog/sap-ecc-vs-sap-s4hana/.

[3]

SAP, "SAP Leanix," [Online]. Available: https://www.leanix.net/en/wiki/tech-transformation/s4hana-greenfield-vs-brownfield-approach.

[4]

SAP, SAP Learning, [Online]. Available: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/managing-clean-core-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud.

[5]

SAP, May 2025. [Online]. Available: https://www.sap.com/resources/what-is-a-clean-core.

[6]

SAP, "SAP," 12 July 2023. [Online]. Available: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FZ8CYsNqhZU.

[7]

gsimeone, "SAP Community," [Online]. Available: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/what-is-sap-clean-core-with-a-sap-btp-strategy/ba-p/13561226.

[8]

B. Berkebile, "NTTDATA," [Online]. Available: https://nttdata-solutions.com/us/blog/sap-clean-core-strategy-what-you-need-to-know/.

entry.title: Building a RAG Bot on SAP BTP With Hana Cloud Vector Engine and AI Core
entry.content:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a method for improving the output of large language models (LLMs). While LLMs are trained on vast amounts of data, they may lack access to proprietary or enterprise-specific information behind paywalls, or other custom data needed to generate accurate results. RAG supplements the LLM’s knowledge by retrieving relevant external information, making its outputs more accurate, relevant, and useful in a cost-effective way.

Key Challenges of LLMs Solved by RAG Bots

  • Presenting False Information: LLMs can hallucinate when they lack the correct answer, often providing inaccurate responses that may appear convincing, which can lead to wrong decisions.
  • Outdated Responses: LLMs are essentially prediction machines, generating answers based on their training data. As a result, they may provide outdated information if it falls beyond their knowledge cutoff.
  • Terminology Differences: Natural languages like English, Spanish, or French are subjective, and the same term can have multiple meanings. LLMs may misunderstand context, leading to incorrect answers.

RAG bots address these challenges by supplementing LLMs with relevant, up-to-date information, making them a cost-effective and reliable way to enhance AI outputs.

To complete this project we will need

  • Data not already accessible to the LLM: There’s no point in using widely known content, like Shakespeare’s plays, as the LLM likely already knows it.
  • A Vector Database: In this example, we’ll use SAP HANA Vector Engine. Many options exist, including AWS vector engines and open-source alternatives. choose the one that fits your needs.
  • A Python Environment: All code will be implemented in Python.
  • An Embedding Model: Here, we use OpenAI’s embedding model, but any freely available model from Hugging Face or similar sources works.

What is a vector database? why do i need it? how does it differ from a real database?

Vector databases store data as mathematical representations called embeddings. Imagine visiting an ice cream shop you’ve been to a hundred times. On your 101st visit, a super-intelligent shopkeeper could instantly guess your preferred flavor based on your previous questions. That’s similar to how a vector database works.

Each piece of data is stored as an embedding, and when you ask a question, it’s converted into an embedding as well. The database then finds the part of your data that is most similar to your query. For example, if your question is meant to return the number 6, and the 12th paragraph of the 200th PDF is embedded as 5.8989898, the database will return it because it’s the closest match.

It’s crucial to embed information carefully. Using inaccurate data or poor embedding methods can result in irrelevant or excessive information being retrieved.

What are embeddings?
An embedding is a vector representation of data generated by an embedding model. In our setup, the model creates embeddings for your data, which are then stored in the HANA vector database. When you ask a question, it is also converted into an embedding, and the database compares it against the stored embeddings to find the most relevant matches.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

What vector embeddings looks like

 

start:

For my data i used this . It is a long 2000 page pdf on aws lambda.

First install these dependencies in your terminal

python-dotenv==1.0.1 # For reading environment variables stored in .env file
langchain==0.2.2
langchain-community==0.2.3
unstructured==0.14.4 # Document loading
# onnxruntime==1.17.1 # chromadb dependency: on Mac use `conda install onnxruntime -c conda-forge`
# For Windows users, install Microsoft Visual C++ Build Tools first
# install onnxruntime before installing `chromadb`

Then import the following before proceeding

 

Step 1: Document Loading

At this point we have our database ready and we have set up our aicore model appropriately; now we can import our document.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Step 2: Splitting the documents

This is a crucial stage because how you split and chunk your documents directly affects the quality of results. Dividing documents into manageable segments allows the system to efficiently create accurate embeddings. When queried, these embeddings produce more precise responses.

Each chunk can also be enriched with metadata, such as page numbers or chapter titles. This helps locate the source if a deeper look is needed. Chunking must be done thoughtfully by headings, topics, or other logical divisions to ensure the system captures the content effectively.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Step 3: Connect to database:

At this stage, we are ready to generate the embeddings and connect them to our HANA database or any other vector database we choose to use.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

There are many resources on how to connect to hana, so for now i will leave this here.

Step 4: Access Embedding Model:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

As explained earlier, an embedding model transforms complex, high-dimensional data into numerical values that machines can easily understand. This makes the data easier to process and allows ML models to identify patterns and relationships.

A vector is a one-dimensional representation of data containing multiple values. For example, a weather vector might be [2, 32, 1000], representing rain (2 = yes), temperature (32°F), and location (1000 = a specific county). Vectors capture relevant information depending on the type of data being represented.

Since this is a text embedding model, it can only create embeddings for textual data. This is important if you want to embed image files etc.

Step 4: Adding Data into HANA.

First, create the schema. You can do this by running a SQL query with the desired schema. This schema will hold the table where all your embeddings are stored.

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

This code will create the table in your database, load your document, split it into chunks, and generate embeddings for each chunk.

When querying the data, your query is first transformed into an embedding and placed in the vector space. The vector database then returns the document chunks that are most similar to your query. This is why chunking is important: it ensures that the system can match your prompt accurately, typically using cosine similarity to find the closest matches.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

After integrating everything into a clean Streamlit UI, here is the final result.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Thanks for reading.

entry.title: Where can I start learning administration in SAP Analytics Cloud?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Administrating SAP Analytics Cloud   learning journey. 

Learning outcome
By the end of this learning journey, you will be able to:

  • Create and manage users and roles, and configure authentication in SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Secure content and data, and transport content within the system
  • Create and manage live and import data connections to on-premise data sources
  • Create and manage live and import data connections to cloud applications
Goals
  • Get started with SAP: Building the basics
  • Develop your expertise: Skill deepening learning
  • Excel in your expertise: Advanced specialization learning
Prerequisites
  • Exploring SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Basic knowledge of Single Sign On (SSO) and SAML Authentication
 
Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 

Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Ariba - Allow Observer User to view the Contract Workspace and Sourcing Project History
entry.content:
Hello!

We have been unsuccessful in finding a solution for the business need of users to have access to view the Contract Workspace or Sourcing Project History, other than adding them as a Project Owner which requires a license.

The users who need this access do not perform any other functions in SAP Ariba that require a license, so paying for that just to view the change history is a challenge. Today, in SAP ECC this detail is available to all users.

In Supplier Lifecycle and Performance, there is a user group "SM Advanced View Access" which allows the user to access the Advanced View in SM which includes visibility into change history. This is an unlicensed user group.

I have not found the equivalent for Contracts & Sourcing. Is there one available that I am missing, or has anyone found alternative solutions to this issue?

I found about four previous customer influence requests over many years asking for this, but it looks like all of them were closed due to low votes. I created a new customer influence request, assuming there isn't a current solution: 

Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

Thanks for any help that can be provided, or feel free to vote on the request linked above!

Vicki Wilson

entry.title: Building a Natural Language to SQL solution using SAP HANA and BTP.
entry.content:
Find the Github for this project here

Introduction: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the ability to process written language like English or other languages and convert it into a format that computers can understand. SQL (Structured Query Language) is a language used to manage and manipulate data within a database system.

SQL has a limited set of operations, making it syntactically simple and easy to learn. This also makes it easier for large language models to generate accurate SQL queries, unlike programming languages like Java, which offer many ways to accomplish the same task.

Natural Language to SQL (NL2SQL) provides an interface that allows non-technical users to interact with databases, explore data, and gather insights without prior SQL knowledge. While a basic understanding of SQL is not required, it is beneficial, as it helps users phrase queries more accurately and obtain better results from the system.

Users who rarely interact with databases no longer need to manually write complex queries. They can simply communicate with the bot and receive accurate responses. Implementing an NL2SQL system saves time and provides a faster, more efficient way to generate real business insights.

Prerequisites for Building This:

  • A working Python environment
  • HANA Cloud
  • AI Core on BTP
  • A dataset to query (for this example, the Spotify listening history dataset from Kaggle)
  • Streamlit to create a chat-style interface for querying the database

My Dataset

 

These are the descriptions of some of the data contained in my dataset. you can find the dataset here, however compared to a real world database; this database is simple and does not have any of the following complications that make a NL2SQL implementation difficult.

  • In a real world scenario the same data can be formatted in many different ways. Sex can be represented as Male, male or M. Different locations have different ways of representing digits eg: 1,000 vs 1.000.
  • If the LLM Lack the domain specific understanding it could misunderstand the user queries.
  • SQL IS Strict with its syntax like every other programming language. if the generated code does not match its strict syntax rules it will fail.
  • Questions can be ambigous and this is why a standard knowledge of SQL is ideal to make this solution work. a simple question about ‘Who is the most popular artist’ can elicit responses such as total minutes played, or who was skipped the least etc.

To address these challenges, we can implement a prompt engineering approach where questions are classified by complexity. More complex questions are checked for ambiguity, and vector embeddings are used to generate accurate and reliable responses.

When a user asks a question, we collect high-quality question/SQL pairs and store them in HANA. The more the system is used, the better it becomes at generating SQL statements. For new questions, vector embeddings are created and searched against the database of existing solutions to find the most relevant response.

But for now this is a basic implementation of the system.

The first step is to create a database schema. this just shows the initial relationship between the tables, how the data can be stored and the columns.
I created this table and my schema in my HANA database as follows, hanas columnar based storage might make it differ from yours if you use another database.

CREATE SCHEMA SpotifyData;

CREATE COLUMN TABLE SpotifyData.StreamHistory (
spotify_track_uri NVARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
ts TIMESTAMP NOT NULL,
platform NVARCHAR(50),
ms_played BIGINT,
track_name NVARCHAR(255),
artist_name NVARCHAR(255),
album_name NVARCHAR(255),
reason_start NVARCHAR(100),
reason_end NVARCHAR(100),
shuffle BOOLEAN,
skipped BOOLEAN
);

I then uploaded my data to hana. Usually a large data source like this wont be manually uploaded but would be gathered from many places into one centralized location to be queried.

 

Importing initial components

Pandas is a library used for working with datasets, HDBCLI is the python interface for working with the HANA Cloud Database.

To access your HANA Database, you will need three important pieces of information. your database Username, your database password and the host vector. I stored mine in an env file
It should look something like this

HANA_VECTOR_USER = ‘*****’
HANA_VECTOR_PASS = ‘*******’
HANA_HOST_VECTOR=‘***********.prodeu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com’

 

I implemented this simple function to run the generated queries into my HANA Database.

 

To generate the prompt i used this code to interact with my ollama model. this was a small model called gemma2.2b.
Alternatively if you have access to AI Core By SAP. or OpenAI, AWS Bedrock, Google’s Gemini you could also query the models as provided.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

This is then used with streamlit to provide an interface which can be used to interact with the databases.

Now i can simply query the database:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

entry.title: Re: SAP CDP integration with HubSpot
entry.content:
Hi @SCHNEIDERT ,

Thank you for sharing the configuration screenshot.
Upon reviewing it, I identified two adjustments needed to successfully ingest data into CDP:
- The Bearer token should follow this format: Bearer your-token-from-hubspot-private-app
- The HubSpot base URL must be set to: https://api.hubapi.com
Apply these changes, save the updated application configuration, and test the connection again.
This should help resolve the issue.

Regards,
Raj
